chunks.text: https://library.embuni.ac.ke/eresources/#gsc.tab=0  1/26 E-Resources What are e-resources  - E-Resources (Electronic Resources)  are information materials that are created, stored, accessed, and used digitally , usually via the internet or a library network.
Libraries provide them to support teaching, learning, research, and reference  without relying on physical copies.
E-Resources include digital materials such as: • E-journals  –These are digital versions of scholarly or professional journals that publish:  Research articles , Reviews , Case studies .

o Key Features:  Peer -reviewed , Updated regularly (monthly, quarterly, etc.) , Searchable and downloadable (PDF/HTML) o Examples of Major E -Journal Databases:  ScienceDirect  – Elsevier journals (science, technology, medicine) , JSTOR  – Archival academic journals (humanities, social sciences) , SpringerLink  – Journals in science, engineering, medicine , IEEE Xplore  – Engineering, computing, and technology journals ,Taylor & Francis Online o • E-books  - are digital versions of books that can be read online or downloaded.

o Key Features: Accessible anytime, anywhere ,Search within text ,No physical wear or loss o Examples of Major E -Book Databases:  EBSCO eBooks , ProQuest Ebook Central ,Springer eBooks , Elsevier eBook Collections , Cambridge Core (Books) o • Online databases  – These are are organized digital collections of information  that libraries subscribe to or provide access to, allowing users to search, retrieve, and use scholarly and professional content online .

o They store large amounts of structured, searchable information  such as:  Journal articles , E- books , Research reports , Theses & dissertations , Newspapers , Statistical data , • Digital theses & dissertations  – These are  digital University  Publication s of student thesis and projects that are available through the  Univers ity digital repository – i.e Dspace – (https://repository.embuni.ac.ke) • Reports, newspapers, and reference tools  - They are accessed through library subscriptions , institutional logins, or open access platforms.
What are Open Access Databases ? - Open Access (OA) databases  are online platforms that provide free, unrestricted access  to research articles, books, data, and other scholarly materials.
Unlike subscription - based databases, anyone can read, download, and share the content without a library login or payment .

Key features:  Free to access  for all users , Often include peer-reviewed  content , Support wider sharing of knowledge , Help researchers and students without subscription access , https://library.embuni.ac.ke/eresources/#gsc.tab=0  2/26 15 major Open Access databases , suitable for library instruction, exams, or training materials .

Library  circulation  refers  to the process  of managing  the lending  and returning  of library materials  to users.
It ensures  that library  resources  are properly  issued,  tracked,  and returned on time.

• Issuing  (borrowing)  library  materials • Receiving  returned  items • Renewing  borrowed  materials • Reserving (holding)  items  for users • Managing  overdue  items  and fines • Updating  borrower  records Circulation  services  help the library  control  the movement  of materials  and ensure  fair access for all users.
The circulation  desk is the main service  point where  users interact  with library  staff for borrowing -related  services.

• Book borrowing  and returns • Membership  registration  and verification • Renewals  and reservations • Overdue  fine inquiries  and payments • User guidance  on locating  materials • Reporting  lost or damaged  items The circulation  desk acts as the link between  users and library  collections.

metadata.section: Services  Offered  at the Circulation  Desk:

chunks.text: OPAC  is an electronic  catalogue  that allows  users to search  the library’s  holdings  online.

• Search  books  by title, author,  subject,  or keyword • Check  availability  status  (on shelf or on loan) • View call numbers  and location • Reserve  or renew  items  (where  enabled) OPAC  helps users locate  materials  quickly  and independently  without  assistance.

metadata.section: What  Users  Can Do Using  OPAC:

chunks.text: Library  materials  are arranged  on shelves  according  to the Library  of Congress  (LC) Classification  Scheme,  which  organizes  books  by subject.

Library  of Congress  (LC) Classification  Scheme: • Uses letters  and numbers  (e.g.,  QA76.73,  HD30.2) • Groups  related  subjects  together • Makes  it easier  to locate  materials  on the shelves Below is a  floor -by-floor listing of University of Embu Library based on the Library of Congress  (LC)  Classification  Scheme .

Ground  Floor:  LC Classes  A – L Class - Subject  Area A - General  Works B - Philosophy,  Psychology,  Religion C - Auxiliary  Sciences  of History D - World  History E - History  of the Americas  (United  States) F- History  of the Americas  (Local  & Latin America) G - Geography,  Anthropology,  Recreation H - Social  Sciences L - Education
Class - Subject  Area J - Political  Science K - Law Second  Floor:  LC Classes  Q – Z Class - Subject  Area Q Q - Science
Z Bibliography,  Library  Science,  Information  Resources
• Each book is assigned  a call number • Books  are arranged  alphabetically  and numerically  on shelves • Users  use the OPAC  call number  to find the exact  shelf location

• OPAC  helps users identify  and locate  materials • Shelves  organize  materials  using the LC Classification  Scheme • Circulation  Desk manages  borrowing  and returns Together,  they ensure  efficient  access,  organization,  and use of library  resources.

chunks.text: STEP 1: SUBMISSION • Students submit assignments via Turnitin portal • Upload documents in accepted formats (PDF, DOC, DOCX) STEP 2: COMPARISON • System compares text with: o Internet sources (billions of web pages) o Academic databases (journals, books, papers) o Student paper repository (previous submissions) STEP 3: REPORT GENERATION • Creates similarity report with percentage score • Highlights matching text segments • Identifies source of matches STEP 4: REVIEW • Students can view reports (if enabled by instructor) • Revise work based on similarity feedback • Resubmit if allowed STEP 5: INSTRUCTOR REVIEW • Instructors review similarity reports • Determine if matches constitute plagiarism • Provide grades and feedback

metadata.chunk_id: The Frequently Asked Questions – University of Embu Library.pdf_28

chunks.text: Plagiarism  is defined  as the act of presenting  other  people’s  ideas,  works,  or statements  as their own from an academic  perspective.
It happens with  students,  researchers, and  other scholars  when  they present  research  reports,  assignments,  and papers  as their own when it is not the case.
It is considered  academic  dishonesty  and can have serious  consequences  in education and research.
• Copying  a paragraph  from a book or website  and not citing  it. • Submitting  a friend’s  essay  as your own.
• Reusing  parts  of your previous  assignment  without  indicating  it. • Using  someone  else’s  ideas  or diagrams  without  credit.

• Always  cite sources  (APA,  MLA, etc.) • Paraphrase  in your own words,  not just change  a few words • Use quotation  marks  for direct  quotes • Keep track  of all sources  used during  research • Use anti-plagiarism  software (e.g.,  Turnitin)  to check  your work What  is Anti-Plagiarism  Software?
Anti-plagiarism software is a tool that detects and prevents plagiarism by comparing  submitted  texts with:Academic  papers,  Books  and journals,  Websites,
Its purpose  is to ensure  academic  integrity  and promote  originality  in research  and assignments.
Turnitin  is a widely  used anti-plagiarism  software  in universities  worldwide. The University uses this software -
• Originality  Check : Detects  similarity  between  submitted  work and existing

• Similarity  Reports : Shows  matched  text and highlights  possible  plagiarism • Citation  Assistance : Suggests  proper  referencing  to avoid  plagiarism • GradeMark : Allows  instructors  to annotate,  comment,  and provide  feedback
• Integration : Works  with learning  management  systems  like Moodle,  Canvas,
• Promotes  academic  honesty • Helps  students improve  citation  skills • Reduces  risk of accidental  plagiarism • Provides  quick  feedback  for instructors

There  is great temptation  to copy-paste  other  people’s  works  due to:- • Availability  of easy to use word processing  software  e.g Microsoft  word • Access  to the internet  and availability  to electronic  information  i.e google  resources, e-books, and e -journals.
• Improved  technology,  scanners,  copiers,  and digital  cameras.
• Always  cite sources  properly  using  APA, MLA, or your university’s  required

• Paraphrase  instead  of copying  text directly • Use the similarity  report  to revise  your work  before  final submission • Check  small  matches  in common  phrases  – not all matches  indicate  plagiarism “Failure  to acknowledge  sources  of information  appropriately  amounts  to plagiarism”
Referencing  - Acknowledging  and Supporting  your ideas during  Research What  is Citation  and  Referencing?
• Citation  - A citation  is a brief acknowledgment  within  the text showing  where information was taken from.
• Referencing  - A reference  is a full bibliographic  description  of the source, listed  at the end of the document in a reference list.
Academic  writing  relies  on more  than just the ideas  and experiences  of one author. It also uses the ideas  and research  of other  sources  such as books,  journal  articles,  websites,  etc.
These  other  sources  may be used to support  the author’s  ideas,  or the author  may be discussing, analyzing, or critiquing other sources.
Referencing  is used to tell the reader  where  ideas from other  sources  have been used in an assignment.

metadata.section: 1. Citing  - Mentioning  the work of others  in your own work.

chunks.text: The reference  list is a list of all the sources  used (and cited)  in an assignment. It is usually alphabetized  according  to the names  of the authors.

metadata.section: 1. Citing  - Mentioning  the work of others  in your own work.

chunks.text: Each entry  in the reference  list contains  detailed  information  about  one source. There  are many  reasons  why it is important

metadata.section: 1. Citing  - Mentioning  the work of others  in your own work.

chunks.text: • It shows  the reader  how your argument  relates  to the entire  perspective  on a
• It properly  credits  the originators  of ideas,  theories,  and research  findings • It shows  the reader  that you can find and use sources  to create  a solid argument.
e.g The more involved  or consulted  people  are, the greater  will be their commitment in its implementation  and sustenance  of the projects.
(Mulwa,  2002). In this example,  “(Mulwa, 2002)” tells the  reader that this information has come from a source  written  by Mulwa,  which  was published  in 2002.
This is a signpost, pointing  the reader to the reference list.
Referencing  is a formal  system:  there  are rules and standards  to follow  when formatting citations  and references.
Many students  find referencing  quite intimidating  at first. Like any skill, it takes  time and patience  to learn.
The examples  above  use APA style,  a format  created  by the American  Psychological Association. It is the most common  referencing  style used at the University  of Embu.
Other  styles  include  MLA style,  Oxford  style,  Harvard  style,  and Chicago  style.
The following  are the recommended  software  and tools that help with creating  or managing references.

• Mendeley  - is a reference  manager  and academic  social  network. It is also a free pdf manager,  take your own fully searchable  library  in seconds,  cite as you write,  and read and annotate  your PDFs on any device • Zotero  - Zotero  helps  to collect,  organize,  cite, and share  research sources.
You can add PDFs,  images,  audio  and video  files, snapshots  of web pages, and really  anything  else.
Zotero automatically  indexes  the full-text content  of your library, enabling  you to find exactly  what you’re  looking  for with just a few keystrokes.
N/B Failure  to properly  acknowledge  sources  is called  plagiarism,  and it can carry significant academic penalties.
